div.head: CORRESPONDENCE
div.p: 13 letters from Manfred Willfort to Schenker, and to Jeanette after Heinrich's death, spanning 1931‒35, offer insights into the workings and personal relationships of Schenker's Friday Seminar, and a hitherto unknown episode in the attempted late revision of Schenker's Theory of Harmony. — Of four items between Moriz and Valerie Violin and Schenker from late 1917, one gives new information about Schenker's mother, Julia, and the behavior of Heinrich's siblings toward her. These items are all new to SDO.

20 letters and postcards from Josef Weinberger spanning 1898 to 1905 deal with publication by Weinberger's company of the Syrian Dances in two versions, and show Weinberger as a director of Universal Edition dealing with the C. P. E. Bach Keyboard Works, the Contribution to Ornamentation, the arrangements of Handel Organ Concertos, and the Instrumentation Table. We see Weinberger rejecting Schenker's early offer to UE of his Theory of Harmony. — 35 letters between Universal Edition and Schenker span 1901 to June 1908; in addition to the above-listed items, these are the opening sallies of what was to become a fiery relationship between Schenker and UE's new director, Emil Hertzka. These items have moved from the former SDO site to the new.

div.head: PROFILES
div.p: Of major importance is the trio of new profiles, Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach; C. P. E. Bach: Klavierwerke; and Beitrag zur Ornamentation, authored by William Drabkin, Hedi Siegel, and Ian Bent. New also are the profile on Schenker's arrangements of Handel Organ Concertos (1905), and an overhaul of the series profile on the Erläuterungsausgabe, and individual profiles for Op. 109, Op. 110, Op. 111, and Op. 101. Other new profiles portray August Artaria, Rudolf Maria Breithaupt, Franz Hardtmuth, and Bernhard Herzmansky; the Doblinger Musikhaus; Gmunden, Richardgasse, Traungasse, and a revision of Reisnerstraße to incorporate Nos 18 and 38.

div.head: DIARIES
div.p: The diaries for 1912 to 1914 are currently being transcribed and translated. They should begin to be accessible on the site by the end of 2016. They cover the publication of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, and the writing and publication of the first two of The Last Five Sonatas of Beethoven. They also contain numerous mini-essays on subjects such as wealth, commerce, and the place of women in society, as well as Schenker's view of the war.
